content: The welcome Sun from sea Freake is returned
And cheereth with his beams the naked earth
Which gains with his coming her apparel
And had his absence six long months mourned.
Out of her fragrant sides she sends to greet him
The rashed primrose and the violet;
While she the fields and meadows doth beset
With flowers
tag: and hangs the trees with pearl to meet him.

content: Amid this hope and joy she doth forget
To kill the hemlock which doth grow too fast
And chill the adder making too much haste
With his black sons revived with the heat;
Till summer comes with diverse colours clad
Much like my Epigrams both good and bad.
Walking the fields a wantcatcher I spied
To him I went
Sir
Here are a dozen
Then you have left no more. No more? quoth he.
Sir I can show you more: the more the worse;
And to his work he went
For all the wants were crept into my purse.
Farewell friend wantcatcher
Thou cannot catch the wants
Come darkest night
Light; leave thy light; fitt for a lightsome soule;
Darknes doth truly sure with mee oprest
Whom absence power doth from mirthe controle:
The very trees with hanging heads condole
Sweet sommers parting
In dying coulers make a griefe-full role;
Soe much (alas) to sorrow are they prest
Thus of dead leaves her farewell carpetts made:
Theyr fall
With leavles
From hopefull greene
If trees
Noe mervaile that I grieve
Where the bee sucks
In a cowslips bell I lie;
There I couch when owls do cry.
On the bats back I do fly
After summer merrily.
Merrily
Under the blossom that hangs on the bough.
As I in hoary winters night stood shivering in the snow
Surprisd I was with sudden heat which made my heart to glow;
And lifting up a fearful eye to view what fire was near
A pretty Babe all burning bright did in the air appear;
Who
column3: such floods of tears did shed

content: As though his floods should quench his flames which with his tears were fed.
Alas! quoth he
Yet none approach to warm their hearts or feel my fire but I!
My faultless breast the furnace is
Love is the fire
The fuel Justice layeth on
The metal in this furnace wrought are mens defiled souls
For which
tag: as now on fire I am to work them to their good

content: So will I melt into a bath to wash them in my blood.
With this he vanishd out of sight and swiftly shrunk away
And straight I called unto mind that it was Christmas day.
The doubt of future foes exiles my present joy
And wit me warns to shun such snares as threaten mine annoy;
For falsehood now doth flow
Which should not be if reason ruled or wisdom weaved the web.
But clouds of joys untried do cloak aspiring minds
Which turn to rain of late repent by changed course of winds.
The top of hope supposed the root upreared shall be
And fruitless all their grafted guile
The dazzled eyes with pride
Shall be unsealed by worthy wights whose foresight falsehood finds.
The daughter of debate that discord aye doth sow
Shall reap no gain where former rule still peace hath taught to know.
No foreign banished wight shall anchor in this port;
Our realm brooks not seditious sects
My rusty sword through rest shall first his edge employ
To poll their tops that seek such change or gape for future joy.
Green groweth the holly
So doth the ivy.
Though winter blasts blow never so high
Green groweth the holly.
As the holly groweth green
And never changeth hue
So I am
Unto my lady true.
As the holly groweth green
With ivy all alone
When flowers cannot be seen
And greenwood leaves be gone
Now unto my lady
Promise to her I make
From all other only
To her I me betake.
Adieu
Adieu
Who hath my heart truly
Be sure
If all the world and love were young
And truth in every Shepherds tongue
These pretty pleasures might me move
To live with thee
Time drives the flocks from field to fold
When Rivers rage and Rocks grow cold
And Philomel becometh dumb
The rest complains of cares to come.
The flowers do fade
To wayward winter reckoning yields
A honey tongue
Is fancys spring
Thy gowns
Thy cap
Soon break
In folly ripe
Thy belt of straw and Ivy buds
The Coral clasps and amber studs
All these in me no means can move
To come to thee and be thy love.
But could youth last
Had joys no date
Then these delights my mind might move
To live with thee
Praisd be Dianas fair and harmless light;
Praisd be the dews wherewith she moists the ground;
Praisd be her beams
Praisd be her power by which all powers abound.
Praisd be her nymphs with whom she decks the woods
Praisd be her knights in whom true honour lives;
Praisd be that force by which she moves the floods;
Let that Diana shine which all these gives.
In heaven queen she is among the spheres;
In aye she mistress-like makes all things pure;
Eternity in her oft change she bears;
She beauty is; by her the fair endure.
Time wears her not: she doth his chariot guide;
Mortality below her orb is placd;
By her the virtue of the stars down slide;
In her is virtues perfect image cast.
A knowledge pure it is her worth to know:
With Circes let them dwell that think not so.
Blow
Thou art not so unkind
As mans ingratitude;
Thy tooth is not so keen
Because thou art not seen
Although thy breath be rude.
Heigh-ho! sing
Most friendship is feigning
Then
This life is most jolly.
Freeze
That dost not bite so nigh
As benefits forgot:
Though thou the waters warp
Thy sting is not so sharp
As friend remembered not.
Heigh-ho! sing
When that I was and a little tiny boy
With hey
A foolish thing was but a toy
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to mans estate
With hey
Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came
With hey
By swaggering could I never thrive
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came unto my beds
With hey
With toss-pots still had drunken heads
For the rain it raineth every day.
A great while ago the world begun
With hey
But thats all one
And well strive to please you every day.
Shall I compare thee to a summers day?
Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May
And summers lease hath all too short a date;
Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines
And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;
And every fair from fair sometime declines
By chance or natures changing course untrimm'd;
But thy eternal summer shall not fade
Nor lose possession of that fair thou owst;
Nor shall death brag thou wanderst in his shade
When in eternal lines to time thou growst:
So long as men can breathe or eyes can see
So long lives this
tag: and this gives life to thee.

content: When I was fair and young
Of many was I sought their mistress for to be.
But I did scorn them all and answered them therefore:
Go
column4: seek some other where; importune me no more.

content: How many weeping eyes I made to pine in woe
How many sighing hearts I have not skill to show
But I the prouder grew and still this spake therefore:
Go
Then spake fair Venus son
Saying: You dainty dame
tag: for that you be so coy

content: I will so pluck your plumes as you shall say no more:
Go
As soon as he had said
tag: such change grew in my breast

content: That neither night nor day I could take any rest.
Wherefore I did repent that I had said before:
Go
Twice or thrice had I lov'd thee
Before I knew thy face or name;
So in a voice
Angels affect us oft
Still when
Some lovely glorious nothing I did see.
But since my soul
Takes limbs of flesh
More subtle than the parent is
Love must not be
And therefore what thou wert
I bid Love ask
That it assume thy body
And fix itself in thy lip
Whilst thus to ballast love I thought
And so more steadily to have gone
With wares which would sink admiration
I saw I had love's pinnace overfraught;
Ev'ry thy hair for love to work upon
Is much too much
For
Extreme
Then
Of air
So thy love may be my love's sphere;
Just such disparity
As is 'twixt air and angels' purity
'Twixt women's love
When Nature made her chief work
In colour black why wrapt she beams so bright?
Would she in beamy black
Frame daintiest lustre
Or did she else that sober hue devise
In object best to knit and strength our sight;
Lest
tag: if no veil these brave gleams did disguise

content: They
Or would she her miraculous power show
That
She even in black doth make all beauties flow?
Both so
Plac'd ever there
To honour all their deaths who for her bleed.
Our storm is past
A stupid calm
The fable is inverted
A block afflicts
Storms chafe
In calms
tag: Heaven laughs to see us languish thus.

content: As steady'as I can wish that my thoughts were
Smooth as thy mistress' glass
The sea is now; and
Seek
As water did in storms
As lead
tag: when a fir'd church becomes one spout.

content: And all our beauty
Like courts removing
The fighting-place now seamen's rags supply;
And all the tackling is a frippery.
No use of lanthorns; and in one place lay
Feathers and dust
Earth's hollownesses
Have no more wind than the upper vault of air.
We can nor lost friends nor sought foes recover
But meteor-like
Only the calenture together draws
Dear friends
tag: which meet dead in great fishes' jaws;

content: And on the hatches
Each one
Who live
Where walkers in hot ovens do not die.
If in despite of these we swim
No more refreshing than our brimstone bath;
But from the sea into the ship we turn
Like parboil'd wretches
Like Bajazet encag'd
Or like slack-sinew'd Samson
Languish our ships. Now as a myriad
Of ants durst th' emperor's lov'd snake invade
The crawling gallies
Might brave our pinnaces
Whether a rotten state
Or to disuse me from the queasy pain
Of being belov'd and loving
Of honour
I lose my end; for here
A desperate may live
Stag
column3: and all which from or towards flies

content: Is paid with life or prey
Fate grudges us all
A scourge
tag: 'gainst which we all forget to pray.

content: He that at sea prays for more wind
Under the poles may beg cold
What are we then? How little more
Is man now
tag: than before he was? He was

content: Nothing; for us
Chance
We have no power
I should not then thus feel this misery.
No spring nor summer beauty hath such grace
As I have seen in one autumnal face.
Young beauties force our love
This doth but counsel
If 'twere a shame to love
Affection here takes reverence's name.
Were her first years the golden age? That's true
But now she's gold oft tried and ever new.
That was her torrid and inflaming time
This is her tolerable tropic clime.
Fair eyes
tag: who asks more heat than comes from hence

content: He in a fever wishes pestilence.
Call not these wrinkles
They were Love's graves
tag: for else he is no where.

content: Yet lies not Love dead here
Vow'd to this trench
And here till hers
He doth not dig a grave
Here dwells he; though he sojourn ev'rywhere
In progress
tag: yet his standing house is here:

content: Here where still evening is
Where no voluptuousness
In all her words
You may at revels
This is Love's timber
There he
Which then comes seasonabliest when our taste
And appetite to other things is past.
Xerxes' strange Lydian love
Was lov'd for age
tag: none being so large as she

content: Or else because
Her youth with age's glory
If we love things long sought
Which we are fifty years in compassing;
If transitory things
Age must be loveliest at the latest day.
But name not winter faces
Lank as an unthrift's purse
Whose eyes seek light within
Whose mouths are holes
Whose every tooth to a several place is gone
To vex their souls at resurrection:
Name not these living death's-heads unto me
For these
I hate extremes
With tombs than cradles
Since such love's natural lation is
My love descend
Not panting after growing beauties. So
I shall ebb on with them who homeward go.
Thou hast made me
Repair me now
tag: for now mine end doth haste

content: I run to death
tag: and death meets me as fast

content: And all my pleasures are like yesterday;
I dare not move my dim eyes any way
Despair behind
Such terror
tag: and my feebled flesh doth waste

content: By sin in it
tag: which it towards hell doth weigh.

content: Only thou art above
By thy leave I can look
But our old subtle foe so tempteth me
That not one hour I can myself sustain;
Thy grace may wing me to prevent his art
And thou like adamant draw mine iron heart.
My galley
Thorough sharp seas in winter nights doth pass
'Tween rock and rock; and eke mine en'my
That is my lord
And every owre a thought in readiness
As though that death were light in such a case.
An endless wind doth tear the sail apace
Of forced sighs and trusty fearfulness.
A rain of tears
Hath done the weared cords great hinderance;
Wreathed with error and eke with ignorance.
The stars be hid that led me to this pain;
Drowned is Reason that should me comfort
And I remain despairing of the port.
Forget this rotten world
Let thine own times as an old story be.
Be not concern'd; study not why
Do not so much as not believe a man.
For though to err
Is far more business than this world is worth.
I'he world is but a carcass; thou art fed
By it
And why shouldst thou
When this world will grow better than before
Than those thy fellow-worms do think upon
That carcass's last resurrection?
Forget this world
tag: and scarce think of it so

content: As of old clothes
To be thus stupid is alacrity;
Men thus lethargic have best memory.
Look upward; that's towards her
We now lament not
She
tag: to whom all this world was but a stage

content: Where all sat heark'ning how her youthful age
Should be employ'd
Some figure of the golden times was hid.
Who could not lack
Because she was the form
Nor could complain that this world was unfit
To be stay'd in
tag: then when she was in it;

content: She
By virtue
She
As courts to princes; she
Star-light enough t' have made the South control
(Had she been there) the star-full Northern Pole;
She
tag: she is gone; she is gone; when thou knowest this

content: What fragmentary rubbish this world is
Thou knowest
tag: and that it is not worth a thought;

content: He honours it too much that thinks it nought.
Think then
column3: that death is but a groom

content: Which brings a taper to the outward room
Whence thou spiest first a little glimmering light
And after brings it nearer to thy sight;
For such approaches doth heaven make in death.
Think thyself labouring now with broken breath
And think those broken and soft notes to be
Division
Think thee laid on thy death-bed
And think that but unbinding of a pack
To take one precious thing
Think thyself parch'd with fever's violence;
Anger thine ague more
Thy physic; chide the slackness of the fit.
Think that thou hear'st thy knell
But that
tag: as bells call'd thee to church before

content: So this to the Triumphant Church calls thee.
Think Satan's sergeants round about thee be
And think that but for legacies they thrust;
Give one thy pride
Give them those sins which they gave thee before
And trust th' immaculate blood to wash thy score.
Think thy friends weeping round
Weep but because they go not yet thy way.
Think that they close thine eyes
That they confess much in the world amiss
Who dare not trust a dead man's eye with that
Which they from God and angels cover not.
Think that they shroud thee up
They reinvest thee in white innocence.
Think that thy body rots
Thy soul exalted so
Think thee a prince
Worms
Think that they bury thee
Lays thee to sleep but a Saint Lucy's night.
CALM was the day
Sweet breathing Zephyrus did softly play
A gentle spirit
Hot Titan's beams
When I whose sullen care
Through discontent of my long fruitless stay
In prince's court
Of idle hopes
Like empty shadows
Walked forth to ease my pain
Along the shore of silver streaming Thames
Whose rutty bank
Was painted all with variable flowers
And all the meads adorned with dainty gems
Fit to deck maidens' bowers
And crown their paramours
Against the bridal day
Sweet Thames
There
A flock of nymphs I chanced to espy
All lovely daughters of the flood thereby
With goodly greenish locks
As each had been a bride;
And each one had a little wicker basket
Made of fine twigs
In which they gathered flowers to fill their flasket
And with fine fingers cropt full featously
The tender stalks on high.
Of every sort
They gathered some; the violet pallid blue
The little daisy
The virgin lily
With store of vermeil roses
To deck their bridegrooms' posies
Against the bridal day
Sweet Thames
With that
tag: I saw two swans of goodly hue

content: Come softly swimming down along the Lee;
Two fairer birds I yet did never see.
The snow which doth the top of Pindus strew
Did never whiter shew
Nor Jove himself
tag: when he a swan would be

content: For love of Leda
Yet Leda was they say as white as he
Yet not so white as these
So purely white they were
That even the gentle stream
Seemed foul to them
To wet their silken feathers
Soil their fair plumes with water not so fair
And mar their beauties bright
That shone as heaven's light
Against their bridal day
Sweet Thames
Eftsoons the nymphs
tag: which now had flowers their fill

content: Ran all in haste
As they came floating on the crystal flood.
Whom when they saw
Their wondering eyes to fill.
Them seemed they never saw a sight so fair
Of fowls so lovely
Them heavenly born
tag: or to be that same pair

content: Which through the sky draw Venus' silver team;
For sure they did not seem
To be begot of any earthly seed
But rather angels
Yet were they bred of Somers-heat they say
In sweetest season
The earth did fresh array
So fresh they seemed as day
Even as their bridal day
Sweet Thames
Then forth they all out of their baskets drew
Great store of flowers
That to the sense did fragrant odours yield
All which upon those goodly birds they threw
And all the waves did strew
That like old Peneus' waters they did seem
When down along by pleasant Tempe's shore
Scattered with flowers
That they appear through lilies' plenteous store
Like a bride's chamber floor.
Two of those nymphs meanwhile
Of freshest flowers which in that mead they found
The which presenting all in trim array
Their snowy foreheads therewithal they crowned
Whilst one did sing this lay
Prepared against that day
Against their bridal day
Sweet Thames
'Ye gentle birds
And heaven's glory
Doth lead unto your lovers' blissful bower
Joy may you have and gentle heart's content
Of your love's complement:
And let fair Venus
With her heart-quelling son upon you smile
Whose smile
All love's dislike
For ever to assoil.
Let endless peace your steadfast hearts accord
And blessed plenty wait upon your board
And let your bed with pleasures chaste abound
That fruitful issue may to you afford
Which may your foes confound
And make your joys redound
Upon your bridal day
Sweet Thames
So ended she; and all the rest around
To her redoubled that her undersong
Which said their bridal day should not be long.
And gentle echo from the neighbour ground
Their accents did resound.
So forth those joyous birds did pass along
Adown the Lee
As he would speak
tag: but that he lacked a tongue

content: Yet did by signs his glad affection show
Making his stream run slow.
And all the fowl which in his flood did dwell
Gan flock about these twain
The rest so far as Cynthia doth shend
The lesser stars. So they
Did on those two attend
And their best service lend
Against their wedding day
Sweet Thames
At length they all to merry London came
To merry London
That to me gave this life's first native source;
Though from another place I take my name
An house of ancient fame.
There when they came
The which on Thames' broad aged back do ride
Where now the studious lawyers have their bowers
There whilom wont the Templar Knights to bide
Till they decayed through pride:
Next whereunto there stands a stately place
Where oft I gained gifts and goodly grace
Of that great lord
Whose want too well now feels my friendless case.
But ah
Old woes but joys to tell
Against the bridal day
Sweet Thames
Yet therein now doth lodge a noble peer
Great England's glory
Whose dreadful name late through all Spain did thunder
And Hercules' two pillars standing near
Did make to quake and fear:
Fair branch of honour
That fillest England with thy triumph's fame
Joy have thou of thy noble victory
And endless happiness of thine own name
That promiseth the same:
That through thy prowess and victorious arms
Thy country may be freed from foreign harms;
And great Elisa's glorious name may ring
Through all the world
Which some brave Muse may sing
To ages following
Upon the bridal day
Sweet Thames
From those high towers this noble lord issuing
Like radiant Hesper when his golden hair
In th'Ocean billows he hath bathed fair
Descended to the river's open viewing
With a great train ensuing.
Above the rest were goodly to be seen
Two gentle knights of lovely face and feature
Beseeming well the bower of any queen
With gifts of wit and ornaments of nature
Fit for so goodly stature;
That like the twins of Jove they seemed in sight
Which deck the baldric of the heavens bright.
They two forth pacing to the river's side
Received those two fair birds
Which
Each one did make his bride
Against their bridal day
Sweet Thames
PIERCE       &         CUDDIE
Cuddie
tag: for shame hold up thy heavye head

content: And let us cast with what delight to chace
And weary thys long lingring Phoebus race.
Whilome thou wont the shepheards laddes to leade
In rymes
Now they in thee
tag: and thou in sleepe art dead.

content: CUDDY
Piers
tag: I have pyped erst so long with payne

content: That all mine Oten reedes bene rent and wore:
And my poore Muse hath spent her spared store
Yet little good hath got
Such pleasaunce makes the Grashopper so poore
And ligge so layd
The dapper ditties
To feede youthes fancie
Delighten much: what I the bett for thy?
They han the pleasure
I beate the bush
tag: the byrds to them doe flye:

content: What good thereof to Cuddie can arise?
PIERS
Cuddie
The glory eke much greater then the gayne:
O what an honor is it
The lust of lawlesse youth with good advice:
Or pricke them forth with pleasaunce of thy vaine
Whereto thou list their trayned willes entice.
Soone as thou gynst to sette thy notes in frame
O how the rurall routes to thee doe cleave:
Seemeth thou dost their soule of sence bereave
All as the shepheard
From Plutoes balefull bowre withouten leave:
His musicks might the hellish hound did tame.
CUDDIE
So praysen babes the Peacoks spotted traine
And wondren at bright Argus blazing eye:
But who rewards him ere the more for thy?
Or feedes him once the fuller by a graine?
Sike prayse is smoke
Sike words bene wynd
PIERS
Abandon then the base and viler clowne
Lyft up thy selfe out of the lowly dust:
And sing of bloody Mars
Turne thee to those
To doubted Knights
And helmes unbruzed wexen dayly browne.
There may thy Muse display her fluttryng wing
And stretch her selfe at large from East to West:
Whither thou list in fayre Elisa rest
Or if thee please in bigger notes to sing
Advaunce the worthy whome shee loveth best
That first the white beare to the stake did bring.
And when the stubborne stroke of stronger stounds
Has somewhat slackt the tenor of thy string:
Of love and lustihed tho mayst thou sing
And carrol lowde
All were Elisa one of thilke same ring.
So mought our Cuddies name to Heaven sownde.
CUDDYE
Indeed the Romish Tityrus
Through his Mecoenas left his Oaten reede
Whereon he earst had taught his flocks to feede
And laboured lands to yield the timely eare
And eft did sing of warres and deadly drede
So as the Heavens did quake his verse to here.
But ah Mecoenas is yclad in claye
And great Augustus long ygoe is dead:
And all the worthies liggen wrapt in leade
That matter made for Poets on to play:
For ever
tag: who in derring doe were dreade

content: The loftie verse of hem was loved aye.
But after vertue gan for age to stoupe
And mighty manhode brought a bedde of ease:
The vaunting Poets found nought worth a pease
To put in preace emong the learned troupe.
Tho gan the streames of flowing wittes to cease
And sonnebright honour pend in shamefull coupe.
And if that any buddes of Poesie
Yet of the old stocke gan to shoote agayne:
Or it mens follies mote be forst to fayne
And rolle with rest in rymes of rybaudrye:
Or as it sprong
Tom Piper makes us better melodie.
PIERS
O pierlesse Poesye
If nor in Princes pallace thou doe sitt:
(And yet is Princes pallace the most fitt)
Ne brest of baser birth doth thee embrace.
Then make thee winges of thine aspyring wit
And
CUDDIE
Ah Percy it is all to weake and wanne
So high to sore
tag: and make so large a flight:

content: Her peeced pyneons bene not so in plight
For Colin fittes such famous flight to scanne:
He
tag: were he not with love so ill bedight

content: Would mount as high
tag: and sing as soote as Swanne.

content: PIERS
Ah fon
tag: for love does teach him climbe so hie

content: And lyftes him up out of the loathsome myre:
Such immortall mirrhor
Would rayse ones mynd above the starry skie.
And cause a caytive corage to aspire
For lofty love doth loath a lowly eye.
CUDDIE
All otherwise the state of Poet stands
For lordly love is such a Tyranne fell:
That where he rules
The vaunted verse a vacant head demaundes
Ne wont with crabbed care the Muses dwell.
Unwisely weaves
tag: that takes two webbes in hand.

content: Who ever casts to compasse weightye prise
And thinks to throwe out thondring words of threate:
Let powre in lavish cups and thriftie bitts of meate
For Bacchus fruite is frend to Phoebus wise.
And when with Wine the braine begins to sweate
The nombers flowe as fast as spring doth ryse.
Thou kenst not Percie howe the ryme should rage.
O if my temples were distaind with wine
And girt in girlonds of wild Yvie twine
How I could reare the Muse on stately stage
And teache her tread aloft in buskin fine
With queint Bellona in her equipage.
But ah my corage cooles ere it be warme
For thy
tag: content us in thys humble shade:

content: Where no such troublous tydes han us assayde
Here we our slender pipes may safely charme.
PIERS
And when my Gates shall han their bellies layd:
Cuddie shall have a Kidde to store his farme.
CUDDIES EMBLEME
Agitante calescimus illo
Hark
tag: hark! the lark at heaven's gate sings

content: And Phoebus 'gins arise
His steeds to water at those springs
On chaliced flowers that lies;
And winking Mary-buds begin
To ope their golden eyes:
With every thing that pretty is
My lady sweet
Arise
Orpheus with his lute made trees
And the mountain tops that freeze
Bow themselves when he did sing:
To his music plants and flowers
Ever sprung; as sun and showers
There had made a lasting spring.
Every thing that heard him play
Even the billows of the sea
Hung their heads
In sweet music is such art
Killing care and grief of heart
Fall asleep
Full many a glorious morning have I seen
Flatter the mountain-tops with sovereign eye
Kissing with golden face the meadows green
Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy;
Anon permit the basest clouds to ride
With ugly rack on his celestial face
And from the forlorn world his visage hide
Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace.
Even so my sun one early morn did shine
With all-triumphant splendour on my brow;
But out
tag: alack! he was but one hour mine;

content: The region cloud hath mask'd him from me now.
Yet him for this my love no whit disdaineth;
Suns of the world may stain when heaven's sun staineth.
How like a winter hath my absence been
From thee
tag: the pleasure of the fleeting year!

content: What freezings have I felt
What old December's bareness everywhere!
And yet this time remov'd was summer's time
The teeming autumn
Bearing the wanton burthen of the prime
Like widow'd wombs after their lords' decease:
Yet this abundant issue seem'd to me
But hope of orphans and unfather'd fruit;
For summer and his pleasures wait on thee
And thou away
Or if they sing
That leaves look pale
